chairs.name: Ball Chair
chairs.description: Eero Aarnio's Ball Chair became an icon of pop design, with its distinctly unnatural space-capsule-like character, strict geometry, and synthetic materials and colours all pointing to a man-made future. Designers had experimented with one-piece chair seats and backs since the 1950s, but Aarnio's design was the first to offer an all-encompassing micro-environment which isolated the sitter. Aarnio even installed telephones in some Ball Chairs, acknowledging that they were like small private rooms.

chairs.name: Bubble Chair
chairs.description image: According to Eero’s notes, the Bubble hangs from the ceiling because ‘there is no nice way to make a clear pedestal.’ It shares the same unique acoustics as the Ball Chair, a little cocoon that shields off the outside world. 'I had the idea of a transparent ball, where light comes from all directions. Acrylic can be heated and blown into shape like a soap bubble, and I knew that dome-shaped skylights were made that way. I contacted a manufacturer and asked if it would be technically possible to blow a bubble big enough for my chair. They said yes.'

chairs.name: Pastil (rocking) Chair
chairs.description: In 1968 Eero received the American Industrial Award for Pastil's comfortable shape and unique aesthetic. Eero himself believes that the design and ergonomics are so good that they don't need cushions. The New York Times also reports that 'Pastil has the ideal design for the human body.'

chairs.name: Mushroom
chairs.description: The Mushroom is one of Eero’s oldest designs and in its fibreglass form is part of the same design family that includes the Ball Chair, Pastil and Tomato. It can be used as a stool or a small table. The fibreglass Mushroom was designed in 1967 by Eero Aarnio.

chairs.name: Garden Egg Chair
chairs.description: Peter Ghyczy's Garden Egg Chair is a pre-eminent example of futuristic post-war design, combining a UFO-like form, bright plastic lacquer and informal lounging quality. The chair was one of Ghyczy's very first designs in his role as Chief Designer for the Polyurethane factory Elastogran GmbH in Lemförde (West Germany), where he was responsible for setting up the Design department and developing model polyurethane products.

chairs.name: Djinn Chair
chairs.Make: Tubular steel frame, foam padding, and nylon jersey upholstery
chairs.description: Organic, futuristic design. Seemingly cut and folded from a single piece of material. Mourgue designed this chair at 24 years old. It's design for lounging rather than something formal reflected the more relaxed events of the 1960s.

chairs.name: President Lounge Chair
chairs.description: Famously seen in Star Trek III: The Search for Spock.

chairs.name: A-line Chairs
chairs.description: The A-line Chair was the first chair ever made by moulded injection in one piece, it's production time, 132 seconds. Just as they were selected for a convent Cloister in South Italy for their ascetic, esthetic and comfortability, they were also selected for jails in USA. Reasons being: they easy to clean and have no legs to be used as weapons.

chairs.name: Tube Chair
chairs.Make: Four hollow cylinders in PVC, foam rubber, and leather
chairs.description: The modular components of this chair can be arranged in any combination to suit the user, and can even be nested together, one inside the other. The chair is made up entirely of synthetic materials, reflecting an increased interest in man-made materials in domestic environments that became popular at this time.

Electronics.name: KD29
Electronics.description: The KD29 lamp's original rounded shape lights up and is mounted on a thin band recreating a “zero-gravity” effect. This lamp offers light and has a tray for pens and small office equipment.

Electronics.name: Model 540P
Electronics.description: Lightweight plastic sphere emits a warm glow atop an elegant slender, chrome-plated tube. Chrome plated, dew drop form base.

Electronics.name: Dania
Electronics.description: The Diana, a sculptural and organic model, was forged in one piece cast aluminium painted white

Electronics.name: Keracolor Keraclonic Sphere
Electronics.description: The Keracolor's design was thought of in 1968, which defines it as a product of sixties modernism, but did not actually go on sale until late 1970. Its spherical shape reminiscent of a cosmonaut’s helmet, a pure example of space-age design.

Electronics.name: RR126
Electronics.designer: Pier Giacomo Castiglioni and Achille Castiglioni
Electronics.Make: Plywood covered with a white plastic laminate
Electronics.description: The RR126 was one of the most famous designs in the history of Italian home stereo, and became a status symbol as soon as it was released in 1966. Its modular speakers could be hung on either side of the record player or disconnected to sit on the floor or any surface. Though it was beautifully symmetric, minimalism was not the factor that set the RR126 apart from the others on this list. Quite the opposite. This unit was anthropomorphized with volume dials for eyes and speakers for ears

Electronics.name: Eclipse
Electronics.description: Joe Colombo Eclipse Space Age Table Lamp for Lightolier, circa 1960s. Orange lacquered metal exterior with a white inside and a rotating screen in the center allows you to control the amount of light and create and 'eclipse' effect as you rotate the button on the top of the lamp.

Electronics.name: Seiko Flip Clocks
Electronics.description: The Seiko Brand was marketed toward the Japanese market. Throughout the sixties, seiko managed to put out an asortment of colorful flip clocks with imaginative forms. Pictured is the Seiko DP 602 Pedestal Clock.

Storage.name: Componibili
Storage.description: Anna Castelli Ferrieri was an Italian architect and designer, one of the first Italian women graduated in architecture and one of the few women in the design sector in those years. She is known for her collaboration with Kartell, a company founded by her husband in 1949 and a pioneer in Italy in research and production of everyday plastic objects.

Storage.name: Magazine Rack 4675
Storage.description: iStoppino is known for being among the first designers to use plastic in his projects and products made famous by companies such as Kartell

Storage.name: Bobby Cabinet
Storage.description: Joe Colombo is known for his many unique designs, in which convenience and effective design were paramount. That's why many of his designs were light and easy to take apart for cleaning.

Storage.name: Tulip Dining Room Set
Storage.Make: Tulip Table base is made from cast Aluminium and is painted white, the top is made from white Formica
Storage.description: Tulip bases made for an icon of the '60s. Their imaginative forms and bright colours came to suggest the spirit of the moment, adding an exciting twist to the rational interior concept of design.
